title: The LIM protein complex establishes a retinal circuitry of visual adaptation by regulating Pax6 α-enhancer activity
abstract: The visual responses of vertebrates are sensitive to the overall composition of retinal interneurons including amacrine cells, which tune the activity of the retinal circuitry. The expression of <italic>Paired-homeobox 6 (PAX6)</italic> is regulated by multiple cis-DNA elements including the intronic α-enhancer, which is active in GABAergic amacrine cell subsets. Here, we report that the transforming growth factor ß1-induced transcript 1 protein (Tgfb1i1) interacts with the LIM domain transcription factors Lhx3 and Isl1 to inhibit the α-enhancer in the post-natal mouse retina. <italic>Tgfb1i1</italic> mice show elevated α-enhancer activity leading to overproduction of Pax6ΔPD isoform that supports the GABAergic amacrine cell fate maintenance. Consequently, the <italic>Tgfb1i1</italic> mouse retinas show a sustained light response, which becomes more transient in mice with the auto-stimulation-defective <italic>Pax6</italic> mutation. Together, we show the antagonistic regulation of the α-enhancer activity by Pax6 and the LIM protein complex is necessary for the establishment of an inner retinal circuitry, which controls visual adaptation.
